title: Tripe ration
data:
**[English]()** • [中文（中国大陆）‎](/wiki/Tripe_ration/zh-CN "Tripe ration/zh-CN")

| % [![Tripe ration.png](/images/0/0a/Tripe_ration.png)](/wiki/File:Tripe_ration.png) |                                       |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------- |
| Name                                                                                | tripe ration                          |
| Base price                                                                          | 15 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")      |
| Nutrition                                                                           | [200](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition")    |
| Turns to eat                                                                        | 2                                     |
| Weight                                                                              | [10](/wiki/Weight "Weight")           |
| Conduct                                                                             | [meat](/wiki/Conduct#Vegan "Conduct") |

A **tripe ration** is a type of [comestible](/wiki/Comestible "Comestible") item that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is [fleshy](/wiki/Fleshy "Fleshy") and not [vegetarian](/wiki/Vegetarian "Vegetarian") or vegan.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Description](#Description)
- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [4 History](#History)
- [5 Origin](#Origin)
- [6 Messages](#Messages)
- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)
- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

Tripe rations make up 14% of all randomly-generated comestibles, which is the second-highest probability among their item type.

[Orcish](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)") [Rangers](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger") start with a stack of 4-8 tripe rations in place of the role's standard [cram rations](/wiki/Cram_ration "Cram ration");[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) all orcish starting characters in non-[Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") roles may also start the game with 1-2 tripe rations as one of their random food items.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) Any [cram rations](/wiki/Cram_ration "Cram ration") or [lembas wafers](/wiki/Lembas_wafer "Lembas wafer") will be replaced with tripe in both cases.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

[Tourists](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist") can start with tripe rations among their initial stacks of food.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

General [stores](/wiki/Store "Store") and delicatessens can sell tripe rations.

[Applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") a [charged](/wiki/Charged "Charged") [horn of plenty](/wiki/Horn_of_plenty "Horn of plenty") has a 129⁄1000 chance (12.9%) of generating a tripe ration or two.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

## Description

When eaten, tripe rations provide 200 [nutrition](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition"), but non-[rotten](/wiki/Rotten "Rotten") tripe also has a 1⁄2 chance of giving the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") [nausea](/wiki/Nausea "Nausea") along with a single [experience point](/wiki/Experience_point "Experience point").[\[6\]](#cite_note-dogfood-6) If the character is a [Caveman](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman"), an [orc](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)") or a non-humanoid [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous") monster (e.g., they became a canine through [lycanthropy](/wiki/Lycanthropy "Lycanthropy")), nausea does not occur.[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

Tripe rations are a [treat](/wiki/Treat "Treat") for carnivorous pets such as [dogs](/wiki/Dog "Dog") and [housecats](/wiki/Housecat "Housecat"), and increases the [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet")'s [apport](/wiki/Apport "Apport") when fed to them. [Throwing](/wiki/Throw "Throw") tripe to a hostile or peaceful [domestic](/wiki/Domestic "Domestic") [canine](/wiki/Canine "Canine") or [feline](/wiki/Feline "Feline") will [tame](/wiki/Tame "Tame") it, as will other forms of meat save for corpses; carrying a tripe ration in open inventory will make a carnivorous pet try to stick closer to to the character.

## Strategy

Tripe rations are primarily useful in the early game for taming hostile domestic animals that can otherwise do serious damage, allowing you to preserve more dependable sources of nutrition. They can also be instrumental in stealing from early shops, especially when money is scarce. Entering a shop that has tripe before your pet does can be useful even if you don't plan to buy the tripe: allowing your pet to eat tripe that you've recently handled raises apport, making the pet more likely to pick up items - doing the same for tripe outside of shops is similarly useful, and keeping tripe in your open inventory also makes pet management slightly easier.

Non-orcish characters can reliably use tripe as a source of [confusion](/wiki/Confusion "Confusion") for reading [scrolls](/wiki/Scroll "Scroll"), similar to [eggs](/wiki/Egg "Egg"). The experience point gained from eating a tripe ration can also be used to regain a recently [drained](/wiki/Drain "Drain") [experience level](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level"), especially for [pacifist](/wiki/Pacifist "Pacifist") [conduct](/wiki/Conduct "Conduct").

## History

Tripe rations first appear in Hack 1.21, a port of [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"),

[NetHack 3.3.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.0 "NetHack 3.3.0") introduces starting races, and [orcish](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)") heroes (except for [Wizards](/wiki/Wizards "Wizards")) can start the game with tripe among their random extra food items[\[8\]](#cite_note-8) - there is intended to be code for their initial inventory that additionally gives them tripe rations in place of cram rations and lembas wafers, which is properly implemented in [NetHack 3.6.2](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.2 "NetHack 3.6.2").[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") and previous versions, including some variants based on those versions, [horses](/wiki/Horse "Horse") can be pacified with a thrown tripe ration.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Tripe](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tripe "wikipedia:Tripe")***

Tripe is a type of edible food made from the stomach linings of various farm animals such as cattle, pigs and sheep, with the mucosal lining removed. Beef tripe is typically the most common, and is made from a cow's stomach; other suitable animals include deer, antelope, goat, ox, and giraffes.

"Dressed tripe" or "washed tripe" is prepared by cleaning the stomachs and trimming the fat off before boiling and bleaching, which turns it a white color; this color is more commonly associated with the tripe seen in market stalls and butchers' shops. Dressed tripe was a popular, nutritious and cheap dish for the British working classes from Victorian times until the latter half of the 20th century, but has since come to be regarded as a pet food - this is the basis for its portrayal in *NetHack*. Dressed tripe remains a popular dish elsewhere in many parts of continental Europe, such as Portugal, Spain, France, and Italy.

## Messages

- Yak - dog food!

  You ate a non-rotten tripe ration and are not an orc; you gain 1 experience point and have a 1⁄2 chance of becoming nauseous for 1d14 (more) turns, unless you are a Caveman or in the form of a carnivorous non-humanoid.[\[6\]](#cite_note-dogfood-6)

- That tripe ration was surprisingly good!

  You ate tripe as a carnivorous non-humanoid.

- Mmm, tripe... not bad!

  As above, while an orc.

- Tastes great! Less filling!

  As above while also [hallucinating](/wiki/Hallucinating "Hallucinating") - this is a reference to the slogan of the [Miller Lite](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miller_Lite "wikipedia:Miller Lite") brand of beer.

## Encyclopedia entry

If you start from scratch, cooking tripe is a long-drawn-out affair. Fresh whole tripe calls for a minimum of 12 hours of cooking, some time-honored recipes demanding as much as 24. To prepare fresh tripe, trim if necessary. Wash it thoroughly, soaking overnight, and blanch, for 1/2 hour in salted water. Wash well again, drain and cut for cooking. When cooked, the texture of tripe should be like that of soft gristle. More often, alas, because the heat has not been kept low enough, it has the consistency of wet shoe leather.

\[ Joy of Cooking, by I. Rombauer and M. Becker ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 119](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/u_init.c#L119)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 852](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/u_init.c#L852): *Extra food for orcs*
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 222](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/u_init.c#L222): *Orcish food substitutions*
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 144](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/u_init.c#L144)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/mkobj.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2219](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkobj.c#L2219): *any comestible that can be randomly generated is eligible*
6. ↑ [6.0](#cite_ref-dogfood_6-0) [6.1](#cite_ref-dogfood_6-1) [src/eat.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1818](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/eat.c#L1818)
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [src/eat.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1807](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/eat.c#L1807)
8. [↑](#cite_ref-8) [NetHack 3.3.0 u\_init.c, line 806](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.0/u_init.c#line806 "NetHack 3.3.0/u init.c")
9. [↑](#cite_ref-9) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.2, line 222](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.2_Release/src/u_init.c#L222)
10. [↑](#cite_ref-10) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.2, line 1055](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.2_Release/src/u_init.c#L1055)

html:
Tripe ration

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
English

 • 中文（中国大陆）‎
%
Name tripe ration
Base price 15 zm
Nutrition 200
Turns to eat 2
Weight 10
Conduct meat

A tripe ration is a type of comestible item that appears in NetHack. It is fleshy and not vegetarian or vegan.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Description
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 History
  • 5 Origin
  • 6 Messages
  • 7 Encyclopedia entry
  • 8 References

Generation

Tripe rations make up 14% of all randomly-generated comestibles, which is the second-highest probability among their item type.

Orcish Rangers start with a stack of 4-8 tripe rations in place of the role's standard cram rations;[1] all orcish starting characters in non-Wizard roles may also start the game with 1-2 tripe rations as one of their random food items.[2] Any cram rations or lembas wafers will be replaced with tripe in both cases.[3]

Tourists can start with tripe rations among their initial stacks of food.[4]

General stores and delicatessens can sell tripe rations.

Applying a charged horn of plenty has a 129⁄1000 chance (12.9%) of generating a tripe ration or two.[5]

Description

When eaten, tripe rations provide 200 nutrition, but non-rotten tripe also has a 1⁄2 chance of giving the hero nausea along with a single experience point.[6] If the character is a Caveman, an orc or a non-humanoid carnivorous monster (e.g., they became a canine through lycanthropy), nausea does not occur.[7]

Tripe rations are a treat for carnivorous pets such as dogs and housecats, and increases the pet's apport when fed to them. Throwing tripe to a hostile or peaceful domestic canine or feline will tame it, as will other forms of meat save for corpses; carrying a tripe ration in open inventory will make a carnivorous pet try to stick closer to to the character.

Strategy

Tripe rations are primarily useful in the early game for taming hostile domestic animals that can otherwise do serious damage, allowing you to preserve more dependable sources of nutrition. They can also be instrumental in stealing from early shops, especially when money is scarce. Entering a shop that has tripe before your pet does can be useful even if you don't plan to buy the tripe: allowing your pet to eat tripe that you've recently handled raises apport, making the pet more likely to pick up items - doing the same for tripe outside of shops is similarly useful, and keeping tripe in your open inventory also makes pet management slightly easier.

Non-orcish characters can reliably use tripe as a source of confusion for reading scrolls, similar to eggs. The experience point gained from eating a tripe ration can also be used to regain a recently drained experience level, especially for pacifist conduct.

History

Tripe rations first appear in Hack 1.21, a port of Jay Fenlason's Hack,

NetHack 3.3.0 introduces starting races, and orcish heroes (except for Wizards) can start the game with tripe among their random extra food items[8] - there is intended to be code for their initial inventory that additionally gives them tripe rations in place of cram rations and lembas wafers, which is properly implemented in NetHack 3.6.2.[9][10]

In NetHack 3.4.3 and previous versions, including some variants based on those versions, horses can be pacified with a thrown tripe ration.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Tripe

Tripe is a type of edible food made from the stomach linings of various farm animals such as cattle, pigs and sheep, with the mucosal lining removed. Beef tripe is typically the most common, and is made from a cow's stomach; other suitable animals include deer, antelope, goat, ox, and giraffes.

"Dressed tripe" or "washed tripe" is prepared by cleaning the stomachs and trimming the fat off before boiling and bleaching, which turns it a white color; this color is more commonly associated with the tripe seen in market stalls and butchers' shops. Dressed tripe was a popular, nutritious and cheap dish for the British working classes from Victorian times until the latter half of the 20th century, but has since come to be regarded as a pet food - this is the basis for its portrayal in NetHack. Dressed tripe remains a popular dish elsewhere in many parts of continental Europe, such as Portugal, Spain, France, and Italy.

Messages

Yak - dog food!
You ate a non-rotten tripe ration and are not an orc; you gain 1 experience point and have a 1⁄2 chance of becoming nauseous for 1d14 (more) turns, unless you are a Caveman or in the form of a carnivorous non-humanoid.[6]
That tripe ration was surprisingly good!
You ate tripe as a carnivorous non-humanoid.
Mmm, tripe... not bad!
As above, while an orc.
Tastes great! Less filling!
As above while also hallucinating - this is a reference to the slogan of the Miller Lite brand of beer.

Encyclopedia entry

If you start from scratch, cooking tripe is a long-drawn-out affair. Fresh whole tripe calls for a minimum of 12 hours of cooking, some time-honored recipes demanding as much as 24. To prepare fresh tripe, trim if necessary. Wash it thoroughly, soaking overnight, and blanch, for 1/2 hour in salted water. Wash well again, drain and cut for cooking. When cooked, the texture of tripe should be like that of soft gristle. More often, alas, because the heat has not been kept low enough, it has the consistency of wet shoe leather.

[ Joy of Cooking, by I. Rombauer and M. Becker ]

References

  1. ↑ src/u_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 119
  2. ↑ src/u_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 852: Extra food for orcs
  3. ↑ src/u_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 222: Orcish food substitutions
  4. ↑ src/u_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 144
  5. ↑ src/mkobj.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2219: any comestible that can be randomly generated is eligible
  6. ↑ 6.0 6.1 src/eat.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1818
  7. ↑ src/eat.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1807
  8. ↑ NetHack 3.3.0 u_init.c, line 806
  9. ↑ src/u_init.c in NetHack 3.6.2, line 222
  10. ↑ src/u_init.c in NetHack 3.6.2, line 1055
